title: Can you apply for a master's degree with associate degree? - Quora

response.answer_text: Actually, depending on the field, in the U.S. there are some programs that allow associate-grad entry to a master’s program. For example, there are ADN to MSN programs in nursing and AAS to MOT programs in occupational therapy. These programs may or may not award a bachelor’s degree along the way. Most require that students have a specific GPA in their bachelor-level courses before they can continue to complete the master’s. If you are planning to pursue a professional master’s degree like a MSN, MSW, MOT, MBA, MPH, etc. be sure you do your research for an accelerated program because you may just find one. Universities are beginning to be much more creative in their delivery to meet students’ needs.

Yes, there are a few online, untraditional universities that will consider your application for a masters program. Your acceptance would depend upon at least a combination of professional acumen within your field of study, certification papers and what your degree would be. University of Essex, Southern Cross University and University of People are 3 of them.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Roksana Parvin Yasmin

response.answer_text: No. The prerequisite for a Master’s is a Bachelor’s Degree. You cannot “pass Go” and go directly to a Master’s. You also generally have to take the GMAT or some other specific entrance exam for graduate school. It’s called “Graduate School” because the students have “graduated” from College/University already. You also have to have the grades and recommendations that will get you into graduate school. It’s meant for high achieving academics.

It is pretty difficult to go straight into a Masters’ program with an Associate degree. There are some schools that may allow you to do a Masters’ degree, but you will have to complete some undergraduate courses that you are missing.

A bachelors degree is a prerequisite for most masters programs. I’m saying “most” because my not being aware of an exception does not mean the exception does not exist. So use your associates to get into a bachelors program, then use the bachelors to get into a masters program.
Actually, you can. If you were a registered nurse (ADN), you can apply to ADN to MSN program. RN to MSN with No BSN Requirement It’s pretty unusual but many do it.
I suspect you cannot apply for a master’s course with an associate degree, you will not meet the academic entry requirements.
No, you need a BA (bachelors) first.
